image.altText: Green rolling hills, photographed under skies with light misty rain.

items.synopsis: A rural community stunned by the sudden loss of friends following suspected mushroom poisoning is grappling with its grief, while under the unfamiliar gaze of national and international media.

title.children: Three suspected mushroom-poisoning deaths put a national spotlight on a community in grief

image.altText: Zecira Misovic falls on the ground

items.synopsis: Earthquakes, goalscoring centre backs and another miraculous, albeit slightly sketchy, save by Swedish goalkeeper Zećira Mušović — here are the five quick hits from Friday's FIFA Women's World Cup quarterfinals.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sweden's super-keeper does it again and an earthquake rocks the FIFA Women's World Cup

image.altText: A woman with pink hair, wearing a black dress, looks stoicly towards the camera with dark green foilage behind her.

items.synopsis: An email with a challenge sent us on a two-year journey to uncover what it's really like behind the closed doors of a rape trial.

title.children: Meagan set a challenge: a positive story about a rape trial. Two years on, here's the verdict

image.altText: Two images stitched together - one shows a Tesco bag of onions, grown in NZ, and the other shows a field in NZ

items.synopsis: Food prices in New Zealand are growing at the fastest rate in more than 30 years, but there are hopes a new grocery regulator will change things.

title.children: 'Why are we getting so badly ripped off?': How one bag of onions in the UK sparked outrage in NZ

image.altText: A man holds a credit card while using a laptop

items.synopsis: Our banks remind us with no irony of the serious need to report fraud, but you shouldn't have to beg for someone to call you back when the most egregious of financial crimes is underway, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: The missing link in why people can lose so much to scams

image.altText: A woman sitting besides a baby rcoker

items.synopsis: Stays in maternity hotels are becoming increasingly popular among Chinese women in Australia, with some new mothers paying up to $50,000 for 26 days.

title.children: Hiro experienced culture shock after giving birth in Australia – so she sought out a nanny to adhere to Chinese postpartum traditions

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: As a fire scientist, I know the unfolding horror — which has killed 53 people so far — is just the beginning. It's a portent of what Australia and other countries will experience in a warmer world, writes David Bowman.

title.children: 'Australia is sleepwalking': The unfolding fire horror in Hawaii holds a message for Australia

image.altText: A shorefront with burnt out cars and buildings.

items.synopsis: Cadaver dogs from California and Washington state are expected to arrive today to help with recovering human remains from the ruins, as firefighters work to extinguish hot spots and smaller fires.

title.children: Search for bodies begins after Maui wildfire, amid questions about whether residents received warning

image.altText: A young white woman with her two young kids. Both are smiling

items.synopsis: After a 10-month Senate inquiry handed down recommendations this week, families experiencing school refusal are hopeful their voices are being heard at last.

title.children: We still don't know the true scale of school refusal — but there are solutions we can look at right now

image.altText: Dimity Taylor stands on her farm wearing a blue and white jumper next to a large solar panel.

items.synopsis: Three-hundred residents in the New South Wales city of Goulburn band together to build their own solar energy project on the edge of town.

title.children: How a 'kitchen table discussion' led to a $5m solar farm funded by residents to provide local power

image.altText: Patient Jennifer Rutz with Leo Sayer

items.synopsis: A music heart-throb of the 1970s and 80s, Leo Sayer finds a new audience by spreading hope through the wards of a Canberra hospital.

title.children: Great pop survivor Leo Sayer is helping cancer patients continue to 'feel like dancing'

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: There has been a lot of work going on behind the scenes in the lead-up to National Cabinet's housing crisis meeting this week – and it could potentially mark an important shift in the way governments think about housing, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: National Cabinet is turning its attention to Australia's housing crisis – and an important shift could be coming

image.altText: woman smiling on a beach selfie

items.synopsis: A man who was among the first on scene to a fatal house fire says he had to leave to make a call to triple-0 because there was no phone coverage.

title.children: Mobile coverage 'worst nightmare' realised as sons remember mum lost to house fire

image.altText: A white, middle-aged woman with blonde hair rests her elbows on the back of a chair with her hands interlaced.

items.synopsis: The Miles Franklin-winning author takes on the patriarchy in her new book, Wifedom: Mrs Orwell's Invisible Life.

title.children: Anna Funder doesn't want to cancel George Orwell – she just wants to set the record straight

image.altText: Montage of six different female mining leaders and workers.

items.synopsis: A growing chorus of women from all levels of the mining sector are speaking out against gendered discrimination, bullying, a lack of opportunity and, at the extreme end, sexual harassment and assault.

title.children: 'Turned a blind eye and accepted it': Women in mining speak out against sexual harassment

image.altText: Three military aircraft fly against a bright blue sky dotted with small white fluffy clouds

items.synopsis: With Taiwan's vice-president due to touch down in the US, observers are anticipating that China will take another opportunity to flex its military muscles by sending PLA aircraft across the median line.

title.children: These charts show China's 'salami-slicing tactic' to normalise military activity in the Taiwan Strait

image.altText: the external view of a building

items.synopsis: A report has found a subsidiary of property developer Toplace, failed to pay $25 million it owed to the tax office in 2022 and claims there's little chance of those funds being recovered.

title.children: Collapsed Sydney developer Toplace entity owes $25m to Australian Tax Office, administrator finds

image.altText: Two Pacific Island men standing on a beach in the shade smiling after receiving a tatau

items.synopsis: With the body a canvas for breathtaking craftsmanship and the transfer of knowledge, the tatau is etched into stretched skin using needle-sharp animal bones.

title.children: Why people are travelling from near and far to get their 'tatau' or tattoo in Tahiti

image.altText: A hand signs a signature with a pen at the end of a form or contract.

items.synopsis: Until now, millions of Australians have been saving in ways that you would expect – cutting back on discretionary items. But there's evidence that thriftiness has evolved to include what many might see as essential items, writes David Taylor.

title.children: From 'thrifty' to 'risky': The financial decisions more Australians are making to pay the mortgage

image.altText: A gorup of four female soccer players in green and gold jerseys hug each other in celebration.

items.synopsis: If you're a novice who wants keep up with the chat about the Matildas, it helps to know the rules of the game. Get up to speed in a few minutes.

title.children: Jumping on the Matildas bandwagon? Here are some key rules to know

image.altText: Sam Kerr of Australia's Matildas runs with the ball away from French players.

items.synopsis: They've never made it to the final four of a World Cup, and the Matildas could meet their match in a former host out for redemption.

title.children: Matildas out to make — and break — history in World Cup quarterfinal

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL captain walks off the ground with teammates and officials wearing a club jacket after being subbed.

items.synopsis: Collingwood will wait until Darcy Moore undergoes scans on his hamstring before making a call on whether the inspirational captain will return before the end of the home-and-away season.

title.children: Magpies not panicking after Moore gets subbed out of win over Cats

image.altText: Hunter Biden is smiling at the camera in front a crowd.

items.synopsis: The appointments signal a deepening investigation into the US president's son, whose history of drugs and personal entanglements have followed his father.

title.children: Special counsel appointed in Hunter Biden probe

image.altText: Michelle Bullock and Philip Lowe

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe says inflation is falling and the worst is over for interest rate increases, but rising property prices are complicating things.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe says 'the worst is over' for interest rate rises, as his term nears its end

image.altText: A man sits on a rock

items.synopsis: A coroner has stopped parents of Luke Gilbert from giving their family impact statement after they refused to edit sections deemed "factually incorrect and offensive" by police.

title.children: Police shooting victim's swastika tattoos analysed as parents barred from making 'offensive' impact statement

image.altText: Sam Lau

items.synopsis: A national advocacy network for Asian Australians says overseas success and recognition is draining Australia's talent pool and watering down representation efforts — so one grassroots group decided to launch its own platform.

title.children: To get Asian-Australian representation in the spotlight, one group's taken it to the stage

image.altText: Laneway in bird's eye view show people waking towards barge

items.synopsis: Dozens of asylum seekers are evacuated from the Bibby Stockholm — a temporary accommodation barge off England's south coast — after health authorities found traces of Legionella bacteria in vessel's water system.

title.children: Asylum-seeker barge evacuated after traces of deadly bacteria found in water

image.altText: Pauline Hanson, dressed in a red jacket, wears a serious expression as she walks out of the Senate.

items.synopsis: A misleading viral video shared by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and anti-Voice campaigners has sparked a wave of racial abuse towards an Aboriginal family and has left another couple feeling "crucified".

title.children: Families distressed after 'highly misleading' video used by anti-Voice campaigners goes viral

image.altText: A primary school with a noticeboard out front that reads "Campbell Primary School".

items.synopsis: An Integrity Commission hears an Education Directorate official was told: "That's not what the minister's office wants" when he revealed the winner of the Campbell Primary School refurbishment tender.

title.children: Education official allegedly told 'that's not what the minister's office wants' after revealing winner of school refurbishment tender

image.altText: Reece Walsh jumps on Billy Walters as Brisbane Broncos teammate Ezra Mam celebrates nearby.

items.synopsis: As they prepare to return home to Lang Park, the Broncos hammer Parramatta 54-10 to extend their winning streak to six matches heading into a bye week.

title.children: Broncos farewell Gabba with nine-try thumping of Eels, who lose Moses to suspected broken cheekbone

image.altText: a group of aboriginal and non-indigenous artists posing with guitars and didgeridoos

items.synopsis: After a career spanning four decades, legendary Northern Territory band Yothu Yindi will tonight be immortalised in the National Indigenous Music Awards Hall of Fame.

title.children: 'Sing loud, play strong': 'Yothu Yindi inducted into National Indigenous Music Awards Hall of Fame
